subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove, and today I’d like to talk a little bit about
being Jewish. I’ve been Jewish all my life, so I know something
about it, but maybe really very little compared to the
4,000 year history of the Jewish religion. Now,
I’d like to mention, if you’re viewing this now that a few of the earlier
segments on the “In Presence” series have dealt with some of my deep personal
experiences having to do with being Jewish. In particular,
I think before you view this segment, it might be very useful for you to view “In
Presence” segment 0007, about my great Uncle Harry, and “In Presence”
segment 0032, about the meaning of life.
I’ve gone through a lot of ups and downs in
relationship to my Jewish upbringing. My
family originally – my father’s family – came from Lubavitch, the area around Lubavitch. They were very
religious Jews. In fact, I’ll tell you an interesting story about my father, who grew up in the tiny town of
Berlin, Wisconsin.
It was so small there was no rabbi, there was no synagogue,
but as I mentioned my grandparents were quite religious, so they hired
somebody to come and live in the home to give my father his Bar Mitzvah lessons.
One day they found the teacher, the Bar Mitzvah instructor,
shaving on the Sabbath, which was considered a sin -
to do any form of work on the Sabbath - so he got fired and my father went to live with my great uncle
Harry, and received his Bar Mitzvah lessons
that way. Now, my father was
minimally a religious man. Once he got into college he became the leader of a
swing band – “High Low & His High Lows” – and he joined the army. He pretty much
left his Orthodox religious background behind him, although he
told me once that every night before he went to sleep he
prayed, and he prayed the prayer – which is one of the major prayers that all
Jewish people pray at every religious service – “Sh’ma Yisra’eil Adonai Eloheinu
Adonai echad” (“Hear, O Israel, the Lord is our God, the Lord is One”).
It’s the essential message of monotheism. So, that’s my father’s religion, and,
you know, it does say in the Bible you should honor your father and your mother.
I thought, well, one way to honor my father and my mother
is not to become deeply involved in the religion that they had mostly rejected. My
mother’s parents were basically –
well, I can put it this way – my mother’s father, my dear grandpa Abe, hated rabbis.
He was very, very secular, and he had
emigrated to the United States from the town of Bialystok,
which had gone back and forth a few times between Russia and Poland.
He was a very unusual man. In fact, one of my cousins has written a couple of books
really about my grandfather – my cousin Steve Roberts – and
I’m showing some of those book covers now.
But, that’s a whole other story, except to say that when my parents were married in New Jersey,
my grandpa Abe managed to find the rabbi who had married
him and my grandmother
Miriam, and that same rabbi officiated at the wedding of my parents.
But that was pretty much it. Although,
growing up in a small town in Wisconsin, we joined the
conservative synagogue there, and I had a religious upbringing. In fact,
I had quite a Bar Mitzvah. At my Bar Mitzvah,
I conducted the entire Friday evening service as well as the normal prayers and blessings
associated with the normal Bar Mitzvah service on a Saturday morning. I
learned all the melodies, and I loved those Jewish melodies – I just loved the music –
and gave a speech that was written for me by the rabbi.
I was quite religious. My sister Pamela – my younger
sister Pamela – was not, even as a young child, and I remember
she was about thirteen saying she wanted nothing to do with the religion. In my mind I was thinking,
“Pamela, how can you forsake the god of Abraham, the god of Jacob, the god of Isaac, the god of our fathers,
who had sacrificed so much to maintain the Jewish religion
for thousands of years against all sorts of oppression?” But
really, by the time I graduated high school, I felt pretty much the same as my sister Pamela, and I
stayed that way, I think, for about thirty years. I just drifted away from the religion until I
had that experience which I mentioned, I think, briefly in
segment 0032 of the “In Presence” series, where I felt a need to come back to it. I
had been in Israel for eight hours, and I
stayed home on Yom Kippur and the Jewish high holiday,
reading the prayers of various prayer books. When I read that poem, which
I briefly summarized in segment 0032,
I was brought to tears. It dawned on me at that time that
so many people of my generation were moving away from
Judaism because of the pain of the Holocaust. I had what is known in
Hebrew as “teshuva” – a return – a turning back to the religion. At that point, I became
active in the synagogue in the town of San Rafael,
California, where we lived at that time. I became very active, as a matter of fact.
I began attending all of the services, even though it was a Reformed synagogue,
which is the most lax of all the branches of Judaism, I believe. I began showing up in the morning for special
minyans, where we would – a minyan is a service where you need at least ten men – and putting on
what are known as “tefillin.” You can see this in some of the old pictures. You wrap these leather straps around
your wrist, because in the same Shema prayer it says, “you shall bind these words upon your forehead and upon your
hands, and you shall remember them,” and you say these prayers as you actually perform this action.
I was doing it and I was becoming so religious. And than,
around that time, my father died.
I attended the funeral in Wisconsin. I was close at the time to the great mystical rabbi, Zalman
Schachter-Shalomi, and his family.
He was on the phone calling me, telling me what to do around the death of my father –
which honestly began to feel a little intrusive – but nonetheless
I was prepared. Now that my father has died I would become even more religious,
I would attend minyans, we should sit Shiva, which is a term for mourning the dead.
I was flying back to California after my father’s funeral, and
I could hear his voice speaking to me, plain as day. He said,
“Son, if you want to become more active in the religion, do it for yourself. You don’t need to do it for me.”
At that moment I felt liberated. I realized that I
didn’t need to do it for me. I thought I was doing it for him.
And if he was speaking to me from a spirit realm and saying, “do it for yourself, don’t do it for me,”
at that moment I felt I had completed my teshuva. I had come back to the religion – I
wasn’t going to stray simply because of the pain of the Holocaust – but now I had completed
that. Interestingly,
my father died shortly before Yom Kippur. I
went to the service – it was the last Jewish service I’ve been at, it’s been nearly 20 years now,
in fact over 20 years. I
was called to say the prayer before the Torah on Yom Kippur, it was a very high honor. I
said the prayer and that’s the last time I’ve been in a synagogue, because
I’m a secular person really. I’m not a religious person, but I’m very proud of being Jewish.
I’m very happy for my Jewish heritage.
There are many, many mysteries about the Jewish religion,
the suffering of the Jewish people and yet, at the same time, the brilliance of the Jewish people.
In a way,
I think the Jewish people are the “chosen people,” not because they received the Torah from Moses –
the five books of Moses, which are the basis of the Jewish religion – for me,
frankly, the Jewish religion took a wrong turn with Moses, but that’s another long story. I
think I’m proud to be a Jew
because of the wonderful religion, and it is – at least I can say I love the music,
not the theology. But also, if you look at today’s culture,
you’ll see Jewish people at the forefront of almost every field. There’s an irony.
I’ve read recently that Ashkenazi Jews, such as myself, on average, have
IQs one standard deviation above the rest of the population. I suspect that,
very likely, the reason for that is because they’ve been persecuted so much, and
those who had the foresight,
perhaps the precognition, to avoid persecution, are the ones who survived and had children.
Maybe that had something to do with the higher intelligence found amongst Ashkenazi Jews. The great
contributions, if you think of the 20th century for example, the great minds of the 20th century:
Sigmund Freud,
Albert Einstein, Karl Marx – for better or worse, with all of his influence – all Jewish. And yet,
Jewish people represent, still, the tiniest, tiniest fraction of the overall population.
Now I can also say, in my lifetime, I’ve experienced a good deal of anti-semitism.
I think I refer to it even as a young child growing up in a small Wisconsin town.
So, what does all of this mean for you?
Well, I can say this, whether you’re Jewish or not, you live in a world with Jewish people, and you might ask yourself
how that impacts you.
Almost everybody I know has some sort of an attitude about the Jews, love them or hate them,
and I’ve certainly known both. So,
it’s a good time just to contemplate, what does it mean for you that there are Jewish people, that there are
different religions?
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you for being with me.
